image.caption: Collection of the U.S. House of Representatives About this object

profileText: A Representative from Minnesota; born in St. Paul, Ramsey County, Minn., April 22, 1906; attended the University of Colorado, Boulder, Colo., 1923-1924; L.L.B., University of Minnesota, Minneapolis, Minn., 1929; lawyer, private practice; member of the Minnesota state house of representatives, 1935-1942; United States Navy, 1942-1946; elected as a Republican to the Eightieth Congress (January 3, 1947-January 3, 1949); unsuccessful candidate for reelection to the Eighty-first Congress in 1948; United States attorney for the district of Minnesota, 1953-1958; unsuccessful candidate for governor of Minnesota in 1958; special assistant, United States Department of Justice, 1960-1961; judge, United States Court of Appeals, District of Columbia Circuit, 1969-1995; presiding judge, United States Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court of Review, 1979-1982; member, United States Sentencing Commission, 1985-1991; died on May 1, 1995, in Potomac, Md.; interment in Union Cemetery, Long Lake, Minn.

researchRecord.name: In the Edward J. Devitt Papers, 1925-1992, 14.75 cubic feet.
researchRecord.description: Other authors include George Edward MacKinnon. An inventory for the papers is available in the repository.

researchRecord.name: In the Minneapolis Council for Israel Council Records, ca. 1917-1984, 3 folders.
researchRecord.description: Other authors include George Edward MacKinnon. An inventory for the papers is available in the repository.

researchRecord.name: In the Oscar F. Hawkins and Family Papers, 1888-1963, 7 cubic feet.
researchRecord.description: Other authors include George Edward MacKinnon. An inventory for the papers is available in the repository.

researchRecord.name: 1927-1995, 178 cubic feet.
researchRecord.description: The papers of George Edward MacKinnon include correspondence, bills, case files, investigative materials, speeches, printed items, and miscellany documenting his political, prosecutorial, and judicial career. The congressional papers focus on domestic economic and political issues and a few aspects of foreign affairs. An inventory for the papers is available in the repository and online.
